error.signature: The above error occurred in the <ComponentName> component. Consider adding an error boundary to your tree to customize error handling behavior.
error.regex: The above error occurred in the <\w+> component|Consider adding an error boundary|ErrorBoundary.*fallback.*not.*function|caught an error

verdict.summary: An unhandled error in a React component crashes the entire app because no Error Boundary is present, or the Error Boundary's fallback prop is misconfigured.

dead_ends.action: Use try-catch inside the render function to catch errors
dead_ends.why_fails: try-catch only works for imperative code; it cannot catch errors thrown during React's rendering phase or in child components

dead_ends.action: Wrap the entire app in a single Error Boundary at the root
dead_ends.why_fails: A single top-level boundary catches everything but replaces the entire UI with fallback; user loses all context and cannot interact with unaffected parts of the app

workarounds.action: Create a class component Error Boundary with getDerivedStateFromError and componentDidCatch
workarounds.how: class ErrorBoundary extends React.Component { state = { hasError: false }; static getDerivedStateFromError(error) { return { hasError: true }; } componentDidCatch(error, info) { logError(error, info); } render() { return this.state.hasError ? <Fallback /> : this.props.children; } }

workarounds.action: Use react-error-boundary library for declarative error boundaries with reset capability
workarounds.how:
import { ErrorBoundary } from 'react-error-boundary';

leads_to.condition: When the error occurs in production build and React shows minified error codes instead of full messages

preceded_by.condition: When an uncaught TypeError in a child component propagates up and crashes the app

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Error Boundary catches JavaScript errors during rendering; Suspense boundary handles async loading states. Both are boundary components but serve different purposes.
